name: 1579_B. Shifting Sort
description:
The new generation external memory contains an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 



For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
prompt:
The new generation external memory contains an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n]. This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element, instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions:

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment.
  2. After selecting these indices, you then replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2.

For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]

Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of shifts and their details.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift details for each test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        # We will perform at most n shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if array == sorted_array:
                break

            # Find the first element that is not in the correct position
            for j in range(n - 1):
                if array[j] > array[j + 1]:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift to correct the order
                    l = j + 1
                    r = n
                    d = 1
                    segment = array[l-1:r]
                    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                    array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                    actions.append((l, r, d))
                    break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sort arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k and a list of tuples representing the cyclic shift operations.
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        
        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue
        
        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = sorted_array.index(array[i])
                
                # Perform a cyclic shift
                l = i + 1
                r = correct_pos + 1
                d = r - l  # Calculate the correct offset
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                if len(actions) >= n:
                    break
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Output interface
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(test_cases)
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts k and a list of shift operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                while r > l and array[r - 1] == sorted_array[r - 1]:
                    r -= 1

                # Calculate the offset for cyclic shift
                d = (r - l) % (r - l + 1)
                if d == 0:
                    d = 1

                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[l - 1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l - 1:r] = shifted_segment

                # Record the action
                actions.append((l, r, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

import typing

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[int]]]) -> typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k and a list of tuples representing the actions taken to sort the array.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Implement a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        # This is a naive approach and may not be optimal but will satisfy the problem constraints
        for i in range(n - 1):
            if array[i] > array[i + 1]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = 1
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[l - 1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l - 1:r] = shifted_segment
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                if array == sorted(array):
                    break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(action[0], action[1], action[2])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: list) -> list:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (list): List of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers.

    Returns:
        list: A list of results for each test case, where each result is a tuple containing
              the number of operations and a list of operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        operations = []

        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j

            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                operations.append(f"{l} {r} {d}")

        results.append((len(operations), operations))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()

    t = int(data[0])
    test_cases = []
    index = 1
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        array = list(map(int, data[index + 1].split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
        index += 2

    # Call the function and get the result
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        print(result[0])  # Number of actions
        for action in result[1]:
            print(action)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: list) -> list:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (list): List of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        list: A list of results for each test case, where each result is a tuple containing the number of actions
              and a list of actions (each action is a tuple of l, r, d).
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                array = array[:l-1] + array[l-1:r][d:] + array[l-1:r][:d] + array[r:]
                actions.append((l, r, d))
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Output interface
    result = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    for res in result:
        print(res[0])  # Number of actions
        for action in res[1]:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts each array in the test cases using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: The number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of actions and a list of actions.
        Each action is represented as a tuple (l, r, d) indicating a cyclic shift.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        actions = []

        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        # A simple strategy to sort using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = array.index(sorted_array[i], i)
                # Perform a cyclic shift to move the element to its correct position
                if correct_pos > i:
                    # Calculate the offset for the cyclic shift
                    d = correct_pos - i
                    # Perform the cyclic shift
                    array[i:correct_pos+1] = array[i+d:correct_pos+1] + array[i:i+d]
                    # Record the action
                    actions.append((i+1, correct_pos+1, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

if __name__ == "__main__":
    # Input interface
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Process the test cases
    result = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for k, actions in result:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of actions and the actions themselves.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]): List of test cases, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]: List of results for each test case, each containing the number of actions and the list of actions.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_a = sorted(a)

        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n):
            if a[i] != sorted_a[i]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = sorted_a.index(a[i], i) - i

                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = a[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                a[l-1:r] = shifted_segment

                # Record the action
                actions.append((l, r, d))

                # Check if sorted
                if a == sorted_a:
                    break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of actions and the actions themselves.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]): List of test cases, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]: For each test case, returns the number of actions and the list of actions.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[i] > array[j]:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift
                    l, r = i + 1, j + 1
                    d = 1
                    segment = array[i:r]
                    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                    array[i:r] = shifted_segment
                    actions.append((l, r, d))
                    if array == sorted(array):
                        break
            if array == sorted(array):
                break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Output interface
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(*action)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts each array in the test cases using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: The number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # We will perform a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n - 1):
            if array[i] > array[i + 1]:
                # Find the smallest element in the unsorted part
                min_index = i + 1
                for j in range(i + 1, n):
                    if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                        min_index = j

                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the smallest element to the correct position
                if min_index != i + 1:
                    # Calculate the offset for the cyclic shift
                    d = min_index - i
                    # Perform the cyclic shift
                    segment = array[i:min_index + 1]
                    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                    array[i:min_index + 1] = shifted_segment
                    actions.append((i + 1, min_index + 1, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input().strip())
        a = list(map(int, input().strip().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of an array to the left by a specified offset, effectively rearranging the elements within that segment.

    'sort using cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The task is to sort the array by performing cyclic shifts on segments of the array, ensuring the number of shifts does not exceed the length of the array.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts performed to sort the array should not exceed the length of the array, n. This means that for an array of length n, you can perform up to n shifts.

# [degree adverb]
    'arbitrary'
    Explanation: The indices l and r for selecting segments and the offset d for shifting are chosen freely within the given constraints.

# [code logic]
    - For each test case, read the length of the array and the array elements.
    - Check if the array is already sorted; if so, output 0 and no actions.
    - If not sorted, identify segments that can be cyclically shifted to move elements into their correct positions.
    - Perform cyclic shifts on identified segments, ensuring the number of shifts does not exceed n.
    - Output the number of shifts and their descriptions for each test case.

# [edge case]
    Input: [1, 2]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no cyclic shifts are needed.

    Input: [3, 1, 2]
    Output: 1
    Explanation: A single shift can sort the array. For example, shifting segment [3, 1] by 1 results in [1, 3, 2].

    Input: [5, 4, 3, 2, 1]
    Output: 4
    Explanation: Multiple shifts are needed to sort this reverse-sorted array. Each shift moves one element into its correct position.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic of checking if the array is sorted and performing necessary shifts will handle these cases naturally.

We will implement a function that sorts the array using cyclic shifts. The approach will involve identifying segments that can be shifted to bring the array closer to a sorted state. We will use a simple algorithm that iteratively selects segments and performs cyclic shifts until the array is sorted. The number of shifts will be kept within the limit of n, as required. We will use Python's list slicing and manipulation capabilities to perform the cyclic shifts efficiently.
Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of the array to the left by a specified offset, effectively rearranging the elements within that segment.

    'sort using cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The task is to sort the array by performing cyclic shifts on segments of the array, with the constraint that the number of shifts should not exceed the length of the array.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts performed to sort the array should be less than or equal to the length of the array. This can be implemented by keeping a counter for the number of shifts and ensuring it does not exceed n.

# [degree adverb]
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
    1. For each test case, read the length of the array and the array elements.
    2. Initialize a counter for the number of cyclic shifts.
    3. While the array is not sorted:
        - Identify segments that can be shifted to bring the array closer to a sorted state.
        - Perform cyclic shifts on these segments.
        - Increment the counter for each shift.
    4. Ensure the number of shifts does not exceed n.
    5. Output the number of shifts and the details of each shift.

# [edge case]
    Test case with already sorted array:
    Input: [1, 2, 3, 4]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no cyclic shifts are needed.

    Test case with all identical elements:
    Input: [5, 5, 5, 5]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted as all elements are identical, so no cyclic shifts are needed.

    Test case with two elements:
    Input: [2, 1]
    Output: 1
    Explanation: A single cyclic shift of the segment [1, 2] will sort the array.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic can handle arrays that are already sorted or have identical elements by simply checking if the array is sorted before performing any shifts.
examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
